software.leonov.common.progress

Class ProgressMonitor

  • java.lang.Object
    • software.leonov.common.progress.ProgressMonitor

  • public class ProgressMonitor
extends Object
    A ProgressMonitor can be used to track the progress of a long running operation.

    This class can be instantiated by calling the create(), withConstantStepSize(long), or withMinMaxSize(long, long) methods, followed by adding one or more ProgressListeners.

    Basic usage: 

    
 final ProgressMonitor progress = ProgressMonitor.create().addProgressListener(event -> ...);

 while (...) {
     ...
     progress.increment();
 }

 progress.completed();

    Maximum value:

    Specifying the maximum value is not mandatory. However, if specified, it's important to note that the progress count cannot surpass the maximum value. If the initially set value proves to be underestimated, it should be adjusted to prevent an IllegalArgumentException when the progress count surpasses it.

    ProgressEvents and step size:

    ProgressEvents are published commensurate with the step size specified at creation. Duplicate events will never be published. Unless the step size is constant, it will progressively increase from the minimum to the maximum specified size. Note that setting or adjusting the maximum value may recalculate the step size.

    Progress completion:

    In typical scenarios completed() should be called when the operation has concluded. In cases where the operation might raise an exception, it may be appropriate to call completed within the finally clause of a try statement. Calling completed multiple times is explicitly permitted and will have no subsequent effect. Attempts to modify the progress count after calling completed will result in an IllegalStateException.

    Thread safety:

    This class is not thread safe. In a concurrent environment access to this class must be synchronized externally. Typically only the increment() or setProgress(long) method are called while the operation is in progress. A simple synchronized block is usually sufficient to ensure thread safety in most use cases: 

    
 while (...) {
     ...
     synchronized(this) {
         progress.increment();
     }
 }
    Author:
    Zhenya Leonov

      • setMaximum

        public ProgressMonitor setMaximum(long maximum)
        Sets the maximum value. This method may be called more than once to reset the maximum value if this ProgressMonitor has not completed.
        Parameters:
        maximum - the maximum value
        Returns:
        this ProgressMonitor instance
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if this ProgressMonitor has completed
        IllegalArgumentException - if maximum < 1 or maximum < progress

      • getMaximum

        public Optional<Long> getMaximum()
        Returns the maximum value.
        Returns:
        the maximum value

      • increment

        public long increment()
        Increments the progress count by 1, publishing a ProgressEvent if necessary.
        Returns:
        the new progress count
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if this ProgressMonitor has completed
        IllegalArgumentException - if the new count > maximum

      • setProgress

        public ProgressMonitor setProgress(long count)
        Sets the progress count, publishing a ProgressEvent if necessary.
        Parameters:
        count - the new progress count
        Returns:
        this ProgressMonitor instance
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if this ProgressMonitor has completed
        IllegalArgumentException - if count < progress or count > maximum

      • getProgress

        public long getProgress()
        Returns the progress count.
        Returns:
        the progress count

      • completed

        public void completed()
        Marks this ProgressMonitor as completed, publishing the final ProgressEvent if necessary. Logically this signifies the end of the operation.

        Calling this method multiple times is always permitted and will have no subsequent effect. Any further attempts to modify the state of this ProgressMonitor will result in an IllegalStateException.

      • isDone

        public boolean isDone()
        Returns whether or not this ProgressMonitor has completed.
        Returns:
        whether or not this ProgressMonitor has completed
